item.title: Comment on Tuesday assorted links by Neurotic
item.description:
RH indicates we do know which half of medicine isn't effective. I don't want to get sucked into that rabbit hole, but there's a problem there that I'm not sure either SA or RH appreciate: medical interventions are a "becoming" not a "being". That is, they're not static. What I mean is that an intervention is context sensitive. Not only does the training of the medical team matter, but the number of cases (training set?) matters too. I'd rather have a mediocre brain surgeon at a 1st rate neurosurgery center (who does several of the procedures a week) than a star surgeon at a small rural hospital (who does a maybe handful of the surgeries per yr). That is, training, practice, and infrastructure/support all matter in distinguishing between "good" and "bad" medicine, and all of those thins are dynamic - changing continually. Good luck trying to distinguish between the "good" and the "bad"- except retrospectively. (Although, there are certainly good ways to assign the probability of a good/bad outcome, given the particular context. Those ways may not be legal, given HIPAA.)

item.title: Comment on False Necessity is the Mother of Dumb Invention by C
item.description:
Think dynamic incentives: replacing low productivity jobs is the surest incentive we have to bring people to the point where they reinvent themselves. And that's just the supply side. I don't see any shortage of demand for low-skilled work: we can do with more automatic cleaners so we can have more gardeners, cashiers so we can have more shop advisors, automated taxis so we can have more barristas, and machine peeled potatoes so we can have more real chefs. So-so AI innovation is fine by me. If anything I am worried that the abundance of low skilled workers is one of the reasons productivity is not growing fast enough. People surely know that one of the theories as to why the industrial revolution started in England, not France, was their shortage of manual labor. That's the positive side. On the normative side, I understand that it is a pitiful state of affairs if young people, willing to build a more prosperous future for themselves, are barred from leaving their dysfunctional states. One can make the argument that facilitating immigration for these young and ambitious people is a moral imperative (it often fails on the practicalities when people insist on awarding identical benefits to the newcomers). But this is a two-way street: perhaps we can also do more to export good governance to countries that are currently incapable of governing themselves and tie this to mutually beneficial free-trade agreement. Quite possibly, the European refugee crisis could have been prevented had Europe agreed to expand its existing free-trade agreement with Turkey to also cover services and public procurement and offered tax incentives for Western companies to settle in designated economic zones near refugee camps.

item.title: Comment on Dean Ball on the new California AI bill (from my email) by Marie
item.description:
The problem with the current trend in AI regulation is that it keeps trying to regulate "AI", rather than what people *do* with AI.

In most cases, either minor tweaks to existing laws and regulations or transparency requirements would seem to handle most of the cases that are concerning, while still allowing for interesting uses.

E.g. make sure that "deep fakes" are properly covered under existing fraud / libel / revenge-porn laws. We already have (pretty good, not perfect) mechanisms for dealing with tension between art, free speech, libel, marketing ... do these really need more than some fine-tuning for the AI case?

E.g. For AI in employment, promotion, admissions, insurance, criminal justice etc. it is probably sufficient to require transparency with respect to inputs and outputs and allow anyone to verify and test the models.

There are plenty of organizations that will be happy, even eager, to test for discrimination, stupidity or bugs (if only to discredit rival products..

E.g. for many applications, clarifying ordinary liability should be reasonable (e.g. medical decision making).

The Act defines “artificial intelligence models” as machine-based systems that can make predictions, recommendations, or decisions influencing real or virtual environments and which can formulate options for information or action. However, the Act does not emphasize AI models generally – rather, it focuses specifically on AI models that it defines as a “covered AI model.” These covered models are those that meet one or both of the following requirements: (1) the model was trained using a quantity of computing power greater than 10^26 integer or floating-point operations or (2) the model has similar performance to that of a state-of-the-art foundation model."

"Safety assessment requirement: Under the Act, developers would be required to assess safety before training a “covered AI model,” ensuring that the models are safe and do not pose a risk to public safety or welfare. This involves making a positive safety determination that the model does not have the capability to enable certain harms, such as the creation of chemical or biological weapons that would result in mass casualties or a cyberattack on critical infrastructure resulting in $500 million or more in damage."

"Third-party model testing: Developers of covered AI models are required to implement a written safety and security protocol which provides sufficient detail for third parties to test the safety of the models they develop."

"Shutdown capability: Under the Act, developers are required to implement a shutdown capability for AI models when such models have not obtained a positive safety determination. This means that developers must be able to deactivate or restrict the AI model's functionalities until they are able to obtain such a determination."

That's from a summary of SB-1047 prepared by the international firm DLA Piper. As one can see, the proposed Act isn't nearly as broad as the alarmists are indicating. What's going on here is the industry, having grown accustomed to its immunity from liability pursuant to Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, recoiling from an effort to prevent the industry from evading liability for damages caused by a limited number of A.I. systems. Indeed, the Act proposed in California is limited, distinguishing A.I. systems that have the capability to enable the kind of harm the Act covers. The "nefarious" actor scenario described in the blog post is a red herring.

item.description:
IDK. I wouldn't worry so much about documentation; open-source communities are surprisingly capable there. The bigger issue is whether any of the CA requirements are inconsistent with the typical open-source licenses (e.g., require a warrantee against harm) and/or the LLAMA license. Even a minor change can be a huge PITA in open-source land due to the distributed copyright ownership.
